title: BATAYAN: A Filipino NLP benchmark for evaluating Large Language Models
author: Jann Railey Montalan (AI Singapore), Jimson Paulo Layacan (Ateneo de Manila University), David Demitri Africa (University of Cambridge), Richell Isaiah Flores (Ateneo de Manila University), Michael T. Lopez II (Ateneo de Manila University), Theresa Denise Magsajo, Anjanette Cayabyab, William Chandra Tjhi (AI Singapore), ...
relevance_why: The benchmark framework and insights into language model performance could inform assessments of generative models applied to audio and text synthesis, relevant to my work in audio generation.
background: BATAYAN is a comprehensive benchmark designed to evaluate the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) in understanding, reasoning, and generating the Filipino language.
contribution: BATAYAN introduces a holistic framework for evaluating LLMs on Filipino language tasks, achieving empirical insights into model performance disparities.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous benchmarks often neglect Filipino or create datasets that do not reflect the language's complexities.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work uniquely combines multiple NLP tasks specific to Filipino, ensuring high-quality representation through native speaker annotations.

key_innovation: Uses a rigorous and culturally informed annotation process to combat translation biases and enhance the evaluation of LLMs in Filipino.
real_world_impact: The benchmark could improve NLP applications in Filipino, fostering better communication technologies in a linguistically diverse region.
limitations: Some tasks may still lack comprehensive coverage of Filipino language nuances.

new_terms.translationese: **Translationese** refers to a style of writing that reflects typical features of the language from which a text has been translated, often resulting in unnatural phrasing in the target language.

open_sourcing: BATAYAN will be released under the Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike 4.0 (CC-BY-SA 4.0) license.
